title: How to Plant English Ivy

steps.headline: Choose the right spot to plant English ivy.
steps.description: English ivy prefers partial sun or filtered shade, but it will grow in full shade. If you plant ivy in an area that is not shaded during the heat of the day, provide the plant with a shade screen for the first 4 to 6 months. Ivy is an invasive plant, so pick an area where it has plenty of room to grow and will not interfere with other plants. Be absolutely certain you want to plant it, as it's invasive, considered a weed in many areas and not allowed in some. See Warnings below.

steps.headline: Check the pH level of the soil before planting.
steps.description: English ivy grows best in a pH of around 7.

steps.headline: Adjust the pH level of your soil if needed.
steps.description: Add hydrated lime to raise the alkalinity, or sulfur to raise the acidity. Follow package directions when adjusting your soil pH, and then test the soil again to check the new pH level.

steps.headline: Till the soil to a depth of 10 to 12 inches (25 to 30 cm) and amend it will organic compost if needed.
steps.description: English ivy grow best in well-drained, fertile soil.

steps.headline: Dig a hole 4 to 6 inches (10 to 15 cm) deep.
steps.description: The hole should be slightly wider than the plant's root base.

steps.headline: Pinch off the bottom few leaves on the plant.
steps.description: This stimulates the growth of the plant and its roots.

steps.headline: Put the roots of the plant into the hole, with the base of the stem at ground level.
steps.description: Fill in the hole with soil.

steps.headline: Water the ivy well after planting to help it get established.
Spread 2 to 3 inches (5 to 7 cm) of mulch around the plant.
steps.description: Mulch helps plants retain moisture and prevents weeds from growing.

text: Choose the right spot to plant English ivy. English ivy prefers partial sun or filtered shade, but it will grow in full shade. If you plant ivy in an area that is not shaded during the heat of the day, provide the plant with a shade screen for the first 4 to 6 months. Ivy is an invasive plant, so pick an area where it has plenty of room to grow and will not interfere with other plants. Be absolutely certain you want to plant it, as it's invasive, considered a weed in many areas and not allowed in some. See Warnings below. Check the pH level of the soil before planting. English ivy grows best in a pH of around 7. Adjust the pH level of your soil if needed. Add hydrated lime to raise the alkalinity, or sulfur to raise the acidity. Follow package directions when adjusting your soil pH, and then test the soil again to check the new pH level. Till the soil to a depth of 10 to 12 inches (25 to 30 cm) and amend it will organic compost if needed. English ivy grow best in well-drained, fertile soil. Dig a hole 4 to 6 inches (10 to 15 cm) deep. The hole should be slightly wider than the plant's root base. Pinch off the bottom few leaves on the plant. This stimulates the growth of the plant and its roots. Put the roots of the plant into the hole, with the base of the stem at ground level. Fill in the hole with soil. Water the ivy well after planting to help it get established.  Spread 2 to 3 inches (5 to 7 cm) of mulch around the plant. Mulch helps plants retain moisture and prevents weeds from growing.
